articles.headline: House Prices Rise Again, but the Pace Could Slow
articles.snippet: Home prices have risen steadily since the spring of 2012, but are now slowing a bit. The Fed’s coming taper, and how it affects mortgage rates, may contribute to that, economists say.
articles.abstract: Home prices have risen steadily since the spring of 2012, but are now slowing a bit. The Fed’s coming taper, and how it affects mortgage rates, may contribute to that, economists say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a great year for the stock market. And it was also a pretty good year for many people’s biggest investment: their homes.

articles.headline: For Stocks, an Amazingly Good Year
articles.snippet: Despite turbulence in Washington, China and Europe, which threatened to pull the world into another recession, stock prices just kept rising in 2013.
articles.abstract: Despite turbulence in Washington, China and Europe, which threatened to pull the world into another recession, stock prices just kept rising in 2013.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the market rally that defied gravity and left many with a case of vertigo.

articles.headline: Power Curbed, Detroit Mayor Faces Big Job
articles.snippet: Mike Duggan must share power with an appointed emergency manager and confront vexing questions about the future of a city that has been losing population for decades.
articles.abstract: Mike Duggan must share power with an appointed emergency manager and confront vexing questions about the future of a city that has been losing population for decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — For some who have been around this city the longest, expectations for a new mayor have by now become understandably low: Turn some streetlights on. Do not get indicted. Wait for the lawyers to get Detroit out of bankruptcy.

articles.headline: Millions Gaining Health Coverage Under Law
articles.snippet: The new moment will test the health law’s central premise — that extending coverage to far more Americans will improve the nation’s health and help many avoid crippling medical bills.
articles.abstract: The new moment will test the health law’s central premise — that extending coverage to far more Americans will improve the nation’s health and help many avoid crippling medical bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Millions of Americans will begin receiving health insurance coverage under the Affordable Care Act on Wednesday after years of contention and a rollout hobbled by delays and technical problems. The decisively new moment in the effort to overhaul the country’s health care system will test the law’s central premise: that extending coverage to far more Americans will improve the nation’s health and help many avoid crippling medical bills.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Abby Goodnough

articles.headline: Old Rivalries Reignited a Fuse in South Sudan
articles.snippet: The conflict in South Sudan is rooted partly in a failure to achieve a lasting reconciliation between rival factions when the country was created in 2011.
articles.abstract: The conflict in South Sudan is rooted partly in a failure to achieve a lasting reconciliation between rival factions when the country was created in 2011.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUBA, South Sudan — Few moments conjure as much fear in South Sudan as the massacre of Bor.

articles.headline: Up Early and in Line for a Marijuana Milestone in Colorado
articles.snippet: Hundreds of tourists and residents across Colorado eagerly took part in the country’s first-ever sales of state-regulated recreational marijuana.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of tourists and residents across Colorado eagerly took part in the country’s first-ever sales of state-regulated recreational marijuana.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — They lined up before dawn and in the snow on Wednesday, baby boomers from Nebraska, retirees from Denver and a young man who had driven all day from Ohio. Some were longtime marijuana users. Some had been arrested for marijuana possession.
